data.title: Love Actually Stars Liam Neeson, Hugh Grant, and More Offer Clues About the Sequel
data.meta_description: The short premieres March 24 in the U.K. and May 25 in the U.S.
data.text:
We already have a few hints about what to expect from the Love Actually sequel, which premieres in the U.K. next week as part of the annual Red Nose Day charity telethon. Hugh Grant’s Prime Minister and Martine McCutcheon’s Natalie still appear to be together after all these years. Andrew Lincoln’s Mark has apparently still not given up on Keira Knightley’s married character (or those oft-mocked cue cards) after over a decade. (Maybe the sequel will involve Mark seeing a counselor?) And Emma Thompson won’t be reprising her character for a heartbreaking reason. On Friday, though, BBC dropped a new video chock full of behind-the-scenes footage and clues as to what we can expect from the film’s 10-minute follow-up.

X content

This content can also be viewed on the site it originates from.

Bill Nighy’s character Billy Mack is still a flashy dresser. Hugh Grant’s character is still Prime Minister, holding press conferences at 10 Downing Street, and dancing.

Despite the fact that Thomas Brodie-Sangster’s Sam was a pre-teen when he made his romantic (though entirely unrealistic) dash through airport security checkpoints to meet Olivia Olson’s Joanna, the two appear to still be in some sort of contact. Maybe they are boyfriend/girlfriend, all these years later! Maybe just classmates! Maybe they have been court-ordered to give middle-school assemblies about the dangers of romantic gestures in airports as part of a plea deal! Who knows?!

But we can infer that Sam was able to avoid juvie, because Brodie-Sangster is shown filming an outdoors scene with Liam Neeson, his onscreen father. In it, the two embrace and, well, we’re not sure what else.

Afterward, Neeson charmed the BBC cameras, telling them it was bizarre being back with the Love Actually cast because “they’ve all aged except me. It’s terrific seeing these kids, especially Thomas. Because he was 11 or 12 [when we filmed].”

Everyone seems thrilled to be back. . . except, perhaps, for Hugh Grant—who has something of a reputation for being a bit of a curmudgeon.

“This nightmare with Richard happens every bloody year,” Grant deadpans of the annual invitation for a Love Actually reunion. (Love Actually writer/director Richard Curtis is the long-time romantic partner of Red Nose Day’s director Emma Freud—which might explain why Curtis & the Love Actually Co. were tempted to reunite in the past.)

“Some years I can fob him off with money,” Grant says. “‘I’m not doing that. Here’s a check.’”

Not everyone is as much of a Love Actually downer, though. McCutcheon had a more rom-com appropriate response to the news that there would be a reunion: “My heart—there was a little skip, a little jump.”

The Love Actually short premieres March 24 in the U.K. and May 25 in the U.S.
